titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jay Katz Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Matthew Gorham and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:26

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection comprises the papers of medical doctor, Yale Law School professor, and bioethicist Jay Katz. The papers document Katz's significant contributions to the field of bioethics, through both his teaching and scholarship, and through his public service and advocacy as a member of two federal committees charged to investigate human medical experiments. The papers consist of correspondence; files pertaining to Katz's work as a member of the Tuskegee Syphilis Ad Hoc Advisory Panel and the Advisory Committee on Radiation Experiments; drafts of speeches delivered by Katz; subject files; files pertaining to classes taught by Katz as a professor at Yale Law School; and drafts of articles and books written by Katz.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jay Katz Papers (MS 1958). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises the papers of medical doctor, Yale Law School professor, and bioethicist Jay Katz. The papers document Katz's significant contributions to the field of bioethics, through both his teaching and scholarship, and through his public service and advocacy as a member of two federal committees charged to investigate human medical experiments. The papers consist of correspondence; files pertaining to Katz's work as a member of the Tuskegee Syphilis Ad Hoc Advisory Panel and the Advisory Committee on Radiation Experiments; drafts of speeches delivered by Katz; subject files; files pertaining to classes taught by Katz as a professor at Yale Law School; and drafts of articles and books written by Katz.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jacob "Jay" Katz was born on October 20, 1922, in Zwickau, Germany, where his father was a business owner. When Adolph Hitler and the Nazi Party came to power in 1933, Katz's family's German citizenship was revoked. His father arranged for him to obtain a Czech passport, and at age sixteen, Katz traveled alone to Prague, and ultimately to the United States by way of Italy and Great Britain. The rest of his family joined him in the United States in 1940.

Katz graduated from the University of Vermont in 1944, and in 1949 he earned his medical degree from Harvard Medical School. Following his education, Dr. Katz completed his internship and residency in New York City, and then enlisted in the United States Air Force, serving as a First Lieutenant and Captain at the Maxwell Air Force Base hospital in Montgomery, Alabama.

Katz's career at Yale University began in 1953 when he was appointed Chief Resident at the Yale School of Medicine's outpatient clinic. He began teaching psychiatry at Yale in 1955, and in 1958 was named Assistant Professor of Psychiatry and Law at Yale. Dr. Katz's work in the areas of medical law and bioethics began when he served on a committee that drafted the Connecticut law that established the terms of patient privilege for psychotherapists and their patients in 1961. This law served as a model for the Federal Rules of Evidence, which are enforced across the United States.

In 1972, Katz was named to serve on a federal committee charged to investigate the Tuskegee Syphilis Experiment, begun in 1932 to study the progression and effects of untreated syphilis in about 400 impoverished African-American men from rural Alabama. The infected men were never told that they had syphilis, and were never treated for it, though they were compensated for their participation in the study with free health care, meals, and burial insurance. The committee concluded that the experiment was unethical, that the participants should have been treated for their infections, and called for greater governmental oversight and protection of subjects in medical studies.

In 1994, Katz was appointed to serve on the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments, charged by President Bill Clinton to investigate 30 experiments in which individuals were unknowingly exposed to radiation. Katz was active on a number of other bioethics issues, as an outspoken proponent of the concept of informed consent, and as an opponent of the use of data gathered during Nazi medical experiments.

Katz was the prolific author of six books and numerous articles, and wrote extensively on topics related to the relationship between medicine, ethics, and law. He died on November 17, 2008, at the age of eighty-six at his home in New Haven, Connecticut.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged into seven series: I. Correspondence, 1961-2003. II. Federal investigation files, 1931-1997. III. Speeches, 1961-1997. IV. Subject files, 1959-1999. V. Teaching files, 1961-2001. VI. Writings, 1972-1997. VII. Electronic files, 1985-1990.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

controlaccess.subject: Bioethics
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments
United States. Tuskegee Syphilis Study Ad Hoc Advisory Panel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises a small assortment of both incoming and outgoing correspondence that primarily concerns Katz's scholarship, writings, and speaking engagements. It includes extensive correspondence from the 1960s and 1970s with Anna Freud, a notable figure in the field of child psychology and the daughter of Sigmund Freud. Anna Freud was a visiting lecturer at Yale Law School during the period documented in the correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises Katz's papers from his service on the Advisory Committee on Radiation Experiments and the Tuskegee Syphilis Ad Hoc Advisory Panel. The papers from the Advisory Committee on Radiation Experiments consist of memoranda and subject files. The majority of the memoranda were written and distributed to Katz and other members of the Advisory Committee by the committee's staff or in some cases, fellow committee members. The memos provide valuable insight into the committee's investigative process, particularly the ethical framework that it developed through which to analyze the experiments in question. The memos also richly document the drafting of the committee's final report, and include drafts and revisions of sections of the report, and comments on the drafts made by committee members. The remainder of the memoranda concern many of the radiation experiments that the committee investigated, including the nuclear weapons tests at the Marshall Islands during the 1940s and 1950s; the Nuclear Energy for the Propulsion of Aircraft (NEPA) project; human plutonium injection experiments at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory during the 1940s; and Operation Paperclip, which involved the recruitment of German scientists to work for the U.S. government following World War II. Many of these memos are accompanied by copies of relevant historical documents, and/or summary reports compiled by committee staff members.

The subject files from the Advisory Committee on Radiation Experiments consist mostly of copies of historical documents concerning the radiation experiments investigated by the committee. These include declassified government documents, meeting minutes, interview transcriptions, and reports. The subject files provide further documentation of the committee's investigation of the NEPA project and the Marshall Islands nuclear weapons tests, and also document investigations into other radiation experiments, including the Operation Teapot nuclear weapons tests of 1955; and medical radiation experiments performed on subjects at the Arctic Aeromedical Laboratory in Alaska, at the Medical College of Virginia, and at Vanderbilt University during the 1940s and 1950s.

The papers from Katz's tenure on the Tuskegee Syphilis Study Ad Hoc Advisory Panel consist of correspondence, copies of historical documents related to the experiment, articles and press clippings documenting the panel's work, and administrative documents pertaining to the panel's investigation. The correspondence includes both incoming and outgoing correspondence, primarily between Katz and other members of the panel. The historical documents consist mostly of copies of correspondence between doctors who participated in the Tuskegee Syphilis Study, as well as copies of periodic reports on the status of the experiment. These materials span the entire course of the experiment, from the 1930s to the early 1970s, with the bulk of the historical documents dating from the 1930s. Administrative records of the advisory panel include a copy of its final report, copies of internal memos, and transcriptions of the proceedings of the panel's meetings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of copies of speeches delivered by Katz that richly reflect his scholarship and activism in the field of bioethics. Materials in the series date from the early 1960s through the late 1990s, spanning almost the entirety of Katz's career. Included are many speeches on the topic of informed consent of medical patients, as well as many that concern his work in the area of human medical experimentation. In many instances, the city and/or venue in which a speech was delivered are specified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of an assortment of files related to Jay Katz's research interests and scholarship. It includes several folders containing research materials on the case of Mary Northern, a Tennessee resident who in the 1970s was the focus of a famous medical ethics case concerning the concept of informed consent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers related to Jay Katz's teaching career at Yale Law School. The files span the full scope of Katz's tenure at Yale Law School from the early 1960s to the early twenty-first century, but there are gaps in the papers, including the entirety of the 1950s, the late 1970s and the early-to-mid 1990s. The papers include class lecture notes, class reading materials, papers related to course proposals and developments, and copies of examinations.

did.unittitle: Psychopathology, source book introduction and table of contents
Task force, development of a course on professional responsibility for medical students
Procreation and the law of family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises scholarly papers and articles written by Jay Katz over the course of his career, though there are some significant gaps in dates, particularly during the 1950s, 1960s and 1980s. The bulk of materials consist of typewritten copies of Katz's writings. In some cases it is specified on a given document whether the copy is a final version or part of a work-in-progress. There are also some photocopies of Katz's published articles, as well as documents related to his publications, including correspondence, reviews, sales figures, and book proposals. There are also several folders pertaining to a proposed book by Katz comparing the Tuskeegee Syphilis experiment with medical experiments conducted at the Dachau concentration camp during World War II. These documents include correspondence regarding the proposal, and drafts of the proposed book's introduction and first three chapters.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of fifty-six 5.25" floppy disks. The disks contain an assortment of documents produced by Jay Katz, including speeches, writings, letters of recommendation, and notes. The titles listed in the inventory are transcriptions of the disk titles as assigned by Katz. Some of the disk titles indicate that they may contain duplicate copies of documents already included in Series III and VI.
